history.narrative: Law 1-17 was introduced in Council and assigned Bill No. 1-58, which was referred to the Committee of the Whole. The Bill was adopted on first and second readings on April 29, 1975 and May 13, 1975, respectively. Signed by the Mayor on June 19, 1975, it was assigned Act No. 1-23 and transmitted to both Houses of Congress for its review.

section.heading: Construction of terms set forth in acts and resolutions.
section.text: For the purposes of any act or resolution of the Council of the District of Columbia, unless specifically provided otherwise:

para.text: Words importing the singular include and apply to several persons, parties, or things.
Words importing the plural include the singular.
With regard to resolutions, words importing 1 gender include and apply to the other gender as well.
Words used in the present tense include the future as well as the present.
The words “person” and “whoever” include corporations, companies, associations, firms, partnerships, societies, and joint stock companies, as well as individuals.
“Officer” includes any person authorized by law to perform the duties of the office.
“Signature” or “subscription” includes a mark when the person making it intended that mark as such.
“Oath” includes affirmation, and “sworn” includes affirmed.
“Writing” includes printing and typewriting and reproductions of visual symbols by photographing, multigraphing, mimeographing, manifolding, or otherwise.
The words “include” and “including” mean “includes, but not limited to” and “including, but not limited to”.

Words such as “stepparent,” “stepmother,” “stepfather,” “stepchild,” “stepsister,” and “stepbrother” are used to indicate a category of a family step-relationship created when an individual who is a parent of a child:
Marries an individual who is not a parent of that child; or
Becomes a domestic partner of an individual who is not a parent of that child by registering the domestic partnership pursuant to § 32-702.

section.heading: Enacting and resolving clauses in acts and resolutions; numbering of sections.

para.text: Each act of the Council of the District of Columbia shall have an enacting clause only in the 1st section of each act and such enacting clause shall be in the following form: “Be it enacted by the Council of the District of Columbia,”.
Each resolution of the Council of the District of Columbia shall have a resolving clause in the following form: “Resolved, by the Council of the District of Columbia,”.
Each section of each act or resolution shall be numbered consecutively.

section.heading: Definition of terms set forth in acts and resolutions.
section.text: For the purposes of any act or resolution of the Council of the District of Columbia, unless specifically provided otherwise:

para.text: The term “Council” means the Council of the District of Columbia established under § 1-204.01.
The term “Mayor” means the Mayor of the District of Columbia established under § 1-204.21.
The term “Act” means an Act of the Congress.
The term “act” means an act of the Council.
The term “District” means the District of Columbia.

para.heading: In general. —
para.text: Notwithstanding any other law, except as provided in subsection (c) of this section, all permanent bills and resolutions shall be accompanied by a fiscal impact statement before final adoption by the Council.

para.heading: Contents. —
para.text: The fiscal impact statement shall include the estimate of the costs which will be incurred by the District as a result of the enactment of the measure in the current and each of the first four fiscal years for which the act or resolution is in effect, together with a statement of the basis for such estimate.

para.heading: Appropriations. —
para.text: Permanent and emergency acts which are accompanied by fiscal impact statements which reflect unbudgeted costs, shall be subject to appropriations prior to becoming effective.

para.heading: Applicability. —
para.text: Subsection (a) shall not apply to emergency declaration, ceremonial, confirmation, and sense of the Council resolutions.
